case_vignette: A 9-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric psychologist by his mother because of poor academic performance. The patient’s mother mentions that his academic performance was excellent in kindergarten and first grade, but his second and third-grade teachers complain that he is extremely talkative, does not complete schoolwork, and frequently makes careless mistakes. They also complain that he frequently looks at other students or outside the window during the class and is often lost during the lessons. At home, he is very talkative and disorganized. When the pediatrician asks the boy his name, he replies promptly. He was born at full term by spontaneous vaginal delivery. He is up-to-date on all vaccinations and has met all developmental milestones on time. A recent IQ test scored him at 95. His physical examination is completely normal. When he is asked to read from an age-appropriate children’s book, he reads it fluently and correctly.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Pediatrics and Neonatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having trouble because I talk a lot in class, don't finish my schoolwork, and I make careless mistakes.
Have you noticed any changes in your mood or energy levels?
No, there haven't been any changes to my mood or energy levels mentioned.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty sleeping or staying awake during the day?
There's no mention of me having trouble sleeping or staying awake during the day.
Have you been experiencing any headaches or dizziness?
No, I haven't had any headaches or dizziness.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty concentrating or remembering things?
Yes, I get easily distracted and have trouble concentrating during lessons.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your memory?
No, there's no mention of me having trouble with my memory.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your attention span?
Yes, I often look at other students or outside the window and get lost during lessons.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your impulse control?
My teachers say I'm extremely talkative and don't complete my schoolwork, which might suggest I have trouble with impulse control.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your self-control?
Yes, I've been talkative and disorganized both at school and at home.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your impulsivity?
Yes, I frequently talk and make careless mistakes, suggesting I act impulsively.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your impulsivity?
Yes, I'm extremely talkative and I often don't finish my schoolwork.
Have you been experiencing any difficulty with your impulsivity?
Yes, I talk a lot and don't finish my schoolwork, indicating impulsivity issues.
Final Diagnosis: Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

The student also has trouble concentrating during lessons and frequently looks at other students or out the window, becoming lost. Teachers have noted that the student is extremely talkative and struggles to complete schoolwork, indicating possible issues with impulse control. The student has also been talkative and disorganized both at school and at home, frequently making careless mistakes, suggesting impulsivity.
